notes: You can swap the entire front clip (fenders, hood, core support, grille) between the 73-80 'Round Eye' and 81-87 'Stacked Headlight' eras. The cab lines match perfectly. Allows you to update an older truck or backdate a newer one.

The Chevy S10 (especially the long bed standard cab) frame is nearly the perfect wheelbase for 1947-1955 Chevy trucks and some 40s/50s Fords. It provides modern suspension, disc brakes, and power steering for a classic body. Requires fabricating body mounts.

partName: Ford F-Series Disc Brake Swap (Dentside to Bumpside)
notes: The entire I-Beam front suspension with disc brakes from a 73-79 F-100/F-150 bolts directly into the older 67-72 trucks (which had drums). It's the easiest way to get power disc brakes on a classic Ford truck. Grab the proportioning valve and booster too.

The 'Vortec' heads (062 or 906 casting) from 96-99 trucks flow significantly better than the older TBI heads. They bolt onto the older TBI blocks but require a specific Vortec-pattern intake manifold and self-aligning rocker arms. Massive torque gain.

Squarebody pickups have 'saddle' tanks outside the frame rails (dangerous in T-bone crashes). You can mount a 31 or 40-gallon Suburban fuel tank between the rear frame rails. Requires moving a crossmember and cutting a fuel filler door in the bed floor.

The solid front axle from a 79-85 Toyota is the holy grail for 86-95 IFS truck owners. It requires a 'SAS Kit' (hangers, shackles) to weld onto the IFS frame. The 85 axle is best because it has extra trussing, but any 79-85 axle works.

The EFI exhaust manifolds from an 87-96 4.9L flow much better than the restrictive log manifold on older carbureted engines. They are essentially a factory split-header design. Requires fabricating a Y-pipe to connect to the exhaust system.
